newsitem.title: USA: Stock prices mixed; awaiting key jobs data.
newsitem.headline: Stock prices mixed; awaiting key jobs data.

text.p: Stock prices were mixed Wednesday, as investors sat on the sidelines awaiting a key employment report on Friday that is expected to help the Federal Reserve decide whether to boost interest rates.
At 1 p.m. EDT, the Dow Jones industrial average was off 3.33 points at 5,645.06.
In the broader market, advancing issues led declines 12-9 on light volume of 198 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange.
The Nasdaq Composite index was up 0.32 to 1,142.61. The American Stock Exchange index slipped 0.44 to 557.35.
In the bond market, the 30-year Treasury bond was off one-half point and its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 7.10 percent from 7.06 percent at Tuesday's close.
"People are not going to be terribly aggressive until the big number due Friday is behind us," said Marshall Acuff, portfolio strategist at Smith Barney.
The August non-farm payrolls report due early Friday is expected to reinforce or shatter doubts whether the Fed will raise or keep interest rates unchanged at its policy-setting meeting on Sept. 24.
The market shrugged off weaker-than-expected July construction spending, which fell 1.4 percent compared with analysts' forecasts for a drop of only 0.2 percent.

"It's really a 'wait and see' feeling until the Friday employment figures," Acuff said. "It has been almost the defining statistic since February for the markets, so it's very reasonable for money managers to sit on their hands until then."
Acuff said the market was bracing for earnings warnings ahead of the start of third-quarter results, which will start to be released in October.
"Equity is still pretty highly valued, and with bonds getting higher yields, its hard for stocks to make much progress," he said.
Meanwhile, the stock of energy companies fell after gaining Tuesday as crude oil prices soared on news of the U.S. military strike against Iraqi targets.
Crude oil prices were up 8 cents at $23.48 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, pausing after soaring $1.15 on Tuesday.
Exxon Corp. fell 1/4 to 83-3/8, Chevron Corp.slipped 7/8 to 59, Mobil Corp. was down 1/2 to 114-7/8, and Texaco Inc. fell 1/8 to 91-5/8.
Among special situations, Office Depot jumped 4 to 19-3/4, after it agreed to be purchased by Staples Inc. Staples shares fell 1-3/8 to 18-1/8.
Paging Partners rose 1/8 to 2 after announcing that it had hired Laidlaw & Co.to help evaluate its strategic alternatives, including the possible sale of the company.
Chateau Properties climbed 3/8 to 26-1/2 after Samuel Zell's Manufactured Home Communities launched a new $26 a share bid for the firm.
Rubbermaid lost 3-3/4 to 22-3/4 after the company said it expected disappointing third quarter earnings.
